sect1.title: Authors and Contributions
sect1.para: The project was supervised by Doc. Petr Tůma.

Jiří Täuber implemented the new Benchmark Manager component. The original Benchmark Manager was completely replaced by the new implementation. The design changes were so big that no source code from the original implementation could be reused. Jiří also worked on the Web Interface, adding support for the new implementations of Benchmark Manager and Results Repository and for the new Task Tree component of the Task Manager. His work on the Benchmark Manager also involved implementing the support for a Xampler benchmark. He was responsible for UML modeling and graphic overviews in the early phase of the project.

Jan Tattermusch designed and implemented the new Results Repository component. The original Results Repsitory was completely replaced by the new implementation. The Derby database was integrated, together with many other technologies (e.g. Hibernate and OW2 ASM bytecode assembling framework). After completing the new Results Repository, Jan cooperated with Jiří on the Xampler benchmark implementation. Jan also designed the mechanism of pluggable modules, which enables the BEEN framework to load external libraries on demand. Next, his work includes support for new types of tasks coded in Jython or in the platform-dependent shell language. He did a lot of code cleanup and refactoring, improved the build system and did most of the improvements connected to Debug Assistant.

Andrej Podzimek mainly worked on the Command Line Interface. He designed and implemented this component from the groud up, including the client program written in C. He also added the Task Tree, a new component of the Task Manager that provides hierarchical grouping of tasks and status overview for groups of tasks. Andrej refactored the Task Manager code and added a load limitation mechanism and integration with the new task identifiers he introduced. He also added many data structures based on the JAXB technology and implemented utility classes for XML access. He did a lot of code refactoring throughout the whole code base. He also read the whole source code and provided a graphic summary of the components in the early phase of the project. Administration of the testing virtual machines was Andrej's long-term task.
Jiří Svoboda joined the WillBeen project, but he never took part in the development. He is no longer a member of the team.

sect1.title: Coding Statistics
sect1.para: The Subversion repository was used to generate coding statistics. Full output from the StatSVN tool can be found in the documentation directory of the BEEN DVD.

The cloc utility was used to generate a detailed overview of programming languages and lines of code. The overview includes both the original code and new code contributed by the WillBeen project. Mamy old components were reimplemented and removed completely. Consequently, it would not make sense to compare the number of lines of code in the original project and the new one. Only the data from StatSVN can provide a sensible overview of code contributions over time.
A considerable amount of work was spent refactoring and bug fixing. This is not surprising, especially considering the size of the project.
